channel.title: Chrome notebook
channel.description:
Well yesterday i noticed a update from google on facebook about this pilot program. So I applied to test out a chrome notebook. I didnt expect to get one but 10 minutes b4 my next class started i got a knock on my door.
it was ups with a box. i was like i didnt order anything. then i opened it and was like omg i actually got one,i was in shock for like the next 3 hours. So far i like it even though it is for testing so i can give feedback to google; I like it. I plan to use it when ever i have internet related tasks to do which can be alot of things.
so far i haven't had much trouble with it but i still have much more to test it on. I doesn't come with java installed but I have read you can install it. So i am trying. I am going to test RS on this. so google "chrome notebook" if you want to know more. Apply if you feel like you want to test and give feedback to help google with their product. post some feedback here as well.
Edit: here is a pic if this isnt good enough i can take another one that will include me. ill just have someone take the pic of me holding it. i tried taking it myself but it looked weird. i plan on making a review on youtube about it later on when i get more use to it. [img]http://www.mediafire.com/imgbnc.php/b123562b4fef8e10b3bfe8e97ea82996f70b2a90289a3fb4e710770e0ed539975g.jpg[/img]
this shows this thread if you zoom in you can see that. also that paper to the right of the picture comes with the notebook. you can also read some of that if you zoom in. i read that they had 60,000 units so idk if that is truly the amount they are giving out or not. i applied within a hour of google posting about this program. my class including my teacher has applied for one also but that was 24+ hours after googles announcement. idk if my speedy application played a role in why i got one, but i applied with accurate information. I truly thought i wouldnt get one.
Note: i never got an email from google saying they were sending me one. it just arrived at my apartment.

item.dc:creator: @zoltanman zoltanman
item.description:
@zoltanman wrote:

I applied also, said I am going to use this at the golf course I work at. See how it would fair with the managers and so forth.

item.title: Chrome notebook
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“k0 twin, post:26, topic:372610”][quote author=abatssk8ter link=topic=468653.msg3426439#msg3426439 date=1291959100]
i do not like this operating system one bit, it’s silly.
if they’re going to have a web-only operating system it better be pretty damn cheap.
[/quote]

That’s still awesome that you got one though.[/quote]

Thx. Ya I feel pretty luck to receive one idk what the odds where probably greater b/c of the time that I applied, but maybe that’s a sign I should buy a lotto ticket(using my program I made to randomly pick lotto numbers; it has picked 4 of the numbers correctly in 1 pick out of 100 picks, the first time I used), lol.

Read full topic

if they’re going to have a web-only operating system it better be pretty damn cheap.[/quote]

That’s still awesome that you got one though.

Read full topic

item.title: Chrome notebook
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

it is different from a gui standpoint and other things. i can see your point of it being web-only; since not everyone has access to the web, but it does have things you can use offline, and im sure in the future some how mostly everyone will have a computer and access to the web. there is so much you can do on the web that people dont know.

i believe the price of the unit would be based on its hardware, since the os is open-source i dont think google would charge for it. for a web-based os the requirements are probably going to be pretty low compared to todays OS’s but depending on what application that will be developed they may need a little more power. i seen somewhere about a $100 notebook but idk if its is anyway related to this.

personally i think google should add some android compatibility to the chrome OS–like the chrome os has access to the android marketplace and can install those applications for use. the computer can still keep its speedy boot and stuff and add more functionality to it–chrome would boot normally allowing you to do web stuff but also when it boots an android compatibility service initiates in the background(kinda like the android phone booting up but you cant see it) and this would allow chrome to use android apps. i should probably suggest this to them soon, but that may void the purpose of the chrome os kinda(but android applications are small and dont take up much room, so idk why this wouldnt be a good idea especially if they want a lot of people to use this).

with the web the endless possiblities of computers become even more endless.

Read full topic

item.title: Chrome notebook
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

this is a product still in development, so this device is for testing. yes the web that is where all computing is going which i support–along with open-source software. it will have applications that dont require internet though. i believe google is trying to get people out of their thoughts of what a technology is and has been and to think outside the box and look at new ideas that have potential to improve users experiences with computers.

Read full topic

item.title: Chrome notebook
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

i can make some screenshots and stuff when i get time. if you want to see a video heres a link on youtube with some information: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vFeD3qGVsrM . what i understand is it has a linux-based core and the gui and most of the workings are based on their browser google chrome. i have almost used the whole months worth of free data from verizon. 100mb isnt very much. so right now im using my windows 7 laptop, b/c i guess the chrome os doesnt know how to connect to an ad-hoc. i use my phones data for the internet on the weekdays with a wifi tether.

my phone plan includes unlimited data and i dont believe my provider could tell the different between my phone and my laptop’s request. since in the end my laptop isnt really visible to anything outside my phone. the phone is the middle man. the laptop sends a request the phone forwards that request as if it was sending the request. when it gets a reply it sends the data to my laptop. so to me i dont really see the difference my laptop isnt making any requests that my phone couldnt request itself–youtube, any web page, etc.

was the picture good enough or do i need to be in it?

edit: No i never received an email, even though after applying it said they would contact me. my classmate was like ya there way of contacting is having it delivered. i applied under developer also, i may not exactly be one right now but thats why im in college. about the ade thing i cant remember there may be an age requirement, especially to receive the verizon 3g service im thinking you would have to be at least 18(idk just a thought).

Read full topic
